text: <!channel>: Hey everyone! We have a bit of a crisis on our hands, as we found out last night that the tamper-resistant outlets aren't slated for release until mid-November. We need to explore contingency plans and I'd like everyone to spend some time thinking about this.
are there any after-market faceplates that could make an outlet tamper-resistant
Is there any possibility of using any of the other outlets we tested (ugly form factor, pesky pairing aside)?
Any other ideas?
I mean...this one still exists: <http://www.insteon.com/2472DWH-outletlinc-dual-band.html>
(Not relevant to current issues, but apparently this is a thing now - pretty cool! <http://www.insteon.com/2845-x22-hidden-door-sensor.html>)
<http://www.cooperindustries.com/content/public/en/wiring_devices/products/electrical_accessories/tamper_resistant_wallplate_cover_trw15.html>
(Here's some for sale: <http://www.amazon.com/Cooper-Wiring-Devices-TRW15V-Wallplate/dp/B00DTWCVYO/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1407350213&sr=8-1&keywords=Tamper+Resistant+Wallplate+Cover+-+TRW15>)

attachments.text: Cooper Wiring Devices TRW15V Wallplate 1G Tamp Resist Dup 15A 125V IV - Extension Cords - <http://Amazon.com|Amazon.com>
attachments.fallback: Cooper Wiring Devices TRW15V Wallplate 1G Tamp Resist Dup 15A 125V IV - Extension Cords - <http://Amazon.com|Amazon.com>

text: Keyword seems to be "child resistant" <http://www.safehomeproducts.com/shp2/category/covers-and-inserts-energy-saver-child-safety-electrical-outlet-insulation-products/electrical-outlets-cover/1090/1090.aspx>

attachments.text: Child safety electrical outlet cover plates and outlet inserts increase child safety and insulate against air leaks through unused electrical outlets to reduce energy costs.
attachments.fallback: Child safety electrical outlet cover plates and outlet inserts increase child safety and insulate against air leaks through unused electrical outlets to reduce energy costs.

text: Clear case style: <http://www.lectralock.com/>
Did we ever look at these?
<http://www.insteon.com/2475SDB-In-LineLinc-Relay.html>
They seem to work with existing outlets?
We didn't ever look at those

Hmm. I'm curious about those faceplates. They look different than the TR ones we have (looks like these have to slide over).I'd like to make sure that they technically meet the tamper resistant requirement
We have tamper resistant faceplates?
<@U02F8LF2X|chewbacca> has joined the channel
<@U02F8LF2X>: <@U0261PCRQ> The Insteon dude suggested this.....<http://www.smarthome.com/2443-222/INSTEON-Micro-On-Off-Module/p.aspx>

attachments.text: The compact Micro On/Off module wires in behind your existing switch, giving you all the remote control of an INSTEON relay switch without sacrificing your unique style. B00B1GHHW6
attachments.fallback: The compact Micro On/Off module wires in behind your existing switch, giving you all the remote control of an INSTEON relay switch without sacrificing your unique style. B00B1GHHW6

text: thoughts?
that doesn't look like it controls an outlet, looks like it controls a switch....
Dustin suggested this (above): <http://www.insteon.com/2475SDB-In-LineLinc-Relay.html>
Electricians were very concerned about volume. Stuffing one of these in a box may be possible. Two (to control top and bottom) would be impossible
Seems like we should be worried about heat?
I read the wire terminals don't accept 12 or 14 gauge wire too
with which?
So you'd have to create a little pigtail with finer gauge wire
dustin's LineLinc relay or the switch thing (is it a switch thing)
The micro on/off module
It gets wired into the box behind a  non-insteon tr outlet or switch
Ok, so it could conceivably work with an outlet too
if there was room...........
what's the heat worry, kat?
any thoughts on the in-linelinc relay thing? should I include it as a potential to IOTAS?
Some reviews on other devices say that the insteon devices can overheat and cause damage to the device. But my knowledge is all second hand.
It's definitely an option. There are a whole bunch of potential issues with it. Kind of scares me
There was also some anecdote I read about needing to power cycle it every two weeks
okay, I'm going to include those links in my update and say that we have a lot of questions and they might not be feasible but we're continuing to review and explore
thanks, everyone
